Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 35. 1. This X-ray was very revealing, according to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Why? 2. He called the action ''dismaying and incomprehensible,'' and said, ''I have a clear conscience.'' Who was speaking? To what was he referring? 3. Lawrence E. Walsh, special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, made the first criminal charge in his inquiry. Who was charged? What were the charges? What did he plead? 4. Mayor Koch's announcement that the city will add 1,931 police officers by June 1988 brought widely shared cheer to city officials. What is particularly noteworthy about the additions? 5. A major Wall Street concern said that it lost $250 million in April, apparently in little more than a week. Wall Street executives could not recall an occasion when a securities company lost so much in so short a time. What is the company and how did it sustain such a loss? 6. A Hall of Fame member will return to the National Basketball Association next year as a coach. Who is he and what team will he join? 7. Moves by Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan and Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board in the United States, represented a concerted approach by the two countries to reduce tension and steady the dollar. What were the moves? 8. Because too few states responded to his request to impose their own standards, Labor Secretary Bill Brock issued rules that will apply to nearly 500,000 migrant farm workers. What are the rules? 9. A British newspaper published details of a book, ''Spycatcher,'' by Peter Wright. Why was this noteworthy? 10. The City of Dallas, the Reagan Administration, a Federal district judge and a group of poor blacks approve of a proposal to destroy the city's most infamous slum. Why? 11. As expected, Vinny Testaverde, the quarterback from Miami, was the first pick of the National Football League college draft, taken by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Other first round choices were more of a surprise. Why? 12. The Interior Department announced its final five-year plan for opening millions of acres of the outer continental shelf to oil and gas exploration. How does the plan differ from the proposal James G. Watt made in 1981 that was widely criticized? 13. New optimism about the nation's farm economy has become evident after years of recession. Why? 14. Benjamin Ernest Linder, an American volunteer working on a rural development project in Nicaragua, was apparently the first American civilian to be killed in the fighting in Nicaragua. Who was blamed for his death? 15. The Supreme Court upheld a law classifying as ''political propaganda'' all foreign government films that might influence public opinion on United States foreign policies. What were the subjects of the three Canadian films that led to the suit? 16. The United Nations Environmental Program announced a step toward ''a meaningful international agreement to protect the ozone layer.'' What was the step?
